awd_titl_txt: Mechanistic Insights Into Chloroplast FtsZ Assembly and Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants possess specialized compartments called chloroplasts that allow them to harvest light energy directly from the sun and convert it to chemical energy through the process of photosynthesis. Photosynthesis produces the organic compounds that comprise the base of the global food chain and are crucial for agricultural production. As plant cells expand during leaf growth, their chloroplast numbers increase dramatically through the process of division, which is crucial for increasing photosynthetic capacity. Consistent with their cyanobacterial origin, chloroplasts inherited several components of their division machinery from the cell division machinery in their prokaryotic ancestors.   Foremost among these is a cytoskeletal protein called FtsZ. In both bacteria and chloroplasts, FtsZ proteins assemble into polymers that form a ring, called the "Z ring", at the center of the cell or organelle that contributes to the constrictive force driving the division process. This project seeks insight into how chloroplasts use these proteins in division and seeks a better understanding of the differences between chloroplast and prokaryotic division.  Broader Impact activities will include participation in the Michigan State University Girl Scout STEM Demo Day, which provides hands-on demonstrations and activities to girls from across the state.  Also, a post-doc will be involved in updating and expanding the Wikipedia page on chloroplast biology to help the general public better understand how chloroplasts work.

Whereas bacterial cell division requires only a single type of FtsZ, chloroplast division requires two functionally distinct types of FtsZ that copolymerize. Previous studies based largely on the FtsZ proteins from a model plant species have led to the hypothesis that their copolymerization enhances polymer rearrangements (dynamics) within the Z ring, which is essential for Z-ring constriction. This project focuses on understanding in greater mechanistic detail how FtsZ pairs cooperate not only in plants, but also in algae, to carry out chloroplast division. Experimental approaches will include analysis of the dynamics of Z rings reconstituted in yeast by fluorescence imaging, a suite of in vitro assembly and biochemical assays, computational modeling to better understand how FtsZ pairs interact in polymers, and advanced microscopy techniques to investigate how the two FtsZs are arranged in polymers. As copolymerization represents a novel and important variation on Z-ring function unique to chloroplasts, study of FtsZ pairs will contribute to broader understanding of the diversity of FtsZ-mediated division systems.

Intellectual merit:

Photosynthesis in plants and algae is carried out by chloroplasts. In order for these organelles to be properly inherited during cell division and increase their numbers during leaf growth, they must divide. Chloroplasts descended from photosynthetic bacteria, from which they acquired key components of their division machinery. The core of the division machinery in bacteria and chloroplasts is FtsZ, a protein which self-assembles into filaments that form a Z ring at the site of division. The Z ring has both a structural role for assembly of the division machinery and a contractile role that generates constrictive force for division. FtsZ filaments have an enzymatic GTPase activity essential for Z-ring dynamics and constriction. Bacteria possess a single FtsZ while chloroplasts possess two. We previously established that both chloroplast FtsZs are required for division, that they coassemble, and that one, called FtsZ2, imparts stability to FtsZ filaments while the other, FtsZ1, promotes filament turnover (assembly, disassembly and reassembly), which must be balanced for chlrooplasts to divide. The overarching goals of this project were to expand understanding of how the two chloroplast FtsZs function together, and gain insight into how the chloroplast FtsZs may have diverged from the single FtsZ in their cyanobacterial ancestor.

Towards these goals, we purified FtsZ1 and FtsZ2 from the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana and investigated their GTPase activities and assembly properties separately and together. We showed that FtsZ2 assembles exceptionally stable filaments, and that FtsZ1 counterbalances this stability by restraining assembly, not by promoting disassembly. We found that FtsZ1 requires its GTPase activity to restrain filament assembly, but that it does not act by enhancing GTPase activity. We discovered that the regions of FtsZ1 and FtsZ2 conferring their GTPase activities, which are very similar in all FtsZs, are also primarily responsible for their distinct roles in filament dynamics. To our knowledge this work is the first to investigate the contributions of these regions to FtsZ dynamics. Our findings provide new evidence that FtsZ1 counterbalances the stabilizing function of FtsZ2 through a mechanism that does not involve a stimulation of GTPase activity, and that both restraining the self-assembly of FtsZ2 and enhancing filament and Z-ring turnover dynamics are critical functions of FtsZ1 in chloroplasts.

We investigated the two FtsZs from a primitive red alga, and found that, similar to the FtsZs in green plants, one promotes filament stability and the other increases filament turnover dynamics. The fact that chloroplasts in photosynthetic organisms separated by over a billion years of evolution both possess one FtsZ with exceptional stability and a second that counteracts this stability underscores the importance of these complementary functions in the regulation of chloroplast FtsZ dynamics.

We purified FtsZ from the cyanobacterium Synechococcus elongatus (SeFtsZ), and compared its assembly properties with those of the chloroplast FtsZs, partly by investigating the effects of its coassembly with FtsZ2 or FtsZ1. The results showed that FtsZ2 is more stable than SeFtsZ, and that SeFtsZ has the ability to counteract this stability by promoting filament disassembly, unlike the mechanism used by FtsZ1. FtsZ1 both restrained the assembly of SeFtsZ without increasing overall GTPase activity and enhanced turnover of coassembled filaments, similar to its effect on FtsZ2. The latter results revealed that these functions of FtsZ1 are not restricted to its interaction with FtsZ2 but are rather an intrinsic property of its coassembly behavior. Our findings, together with our previous work, indicate that the stability- and dynamics-promoting functions present in the single ancestral cyanobacterial FtsZ became partially separated in the two chloroplast FtsZs during their evolution. They also begin to suggest that red algae retained a cyanobacterial-like mechanism for promoting chloroplast Z-ring dynamics whereas green plants evolved a new mechanism. Overall our work has led to new insight into the biochemical mechanisms governing chloroplast Z-ring dynamics.

Because dual FtsZ division systems are present in some mitochondria and Archaea as well as chloroplasts, our research has the potential to impact future studies on mitochondrial and archaeal cell division, potentially uncovering new themes and variations among FtsZ-based division systems in cells and organelles.

Broader impacts:

Three undergraduate students obtained experience in scientific research as part of the project. Two are pursuing careers in medicine, and their research experiences will be invaluable to their understanding of how the scientific process leads to medical advances. Two postdocs and a skilled technician participated in and collaborated closely on the research and resulting publications. Project personnel gained experience and mentoring in scientific writing and presentation skills, collaborative research, and data management. The postdocs and technician helped mentor the undergraduates, learning supervisory and management skills. The postdocs had opportunities to participate in peer review of submitted manuscripts, receiving mentoring in the responsibilities of peer reviewers, including confidentiality, conflict of interest, and best practices for writing constructive reviews. All project personnel except one undergraduate were women, contributing to gender diversity in STEM.
